name_text = Urban

The Archimedes is a new windmill design meant to power small homes and apartments. With an 80 percent efficiency ratio, will this solve the world’s energy problems? Read more: http://vr-zone.com/articles/efficent-wind-turbine/78905.html#ixzz3XUHwEbcm It may not be an exact replica, but it looks very similar, and it spins really fast and without effort just by blowing to it. I used solidworks and a lot of mathematics from archimedes to design it. I added the STL files and the solidworks files, i printed them in a .3 scale. and the size is the one in the video. Here you can find more information about the real project.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i6QyBdPGbFE http://www.gizmag.com/the-archimedes-liam-f1-urban-wind-turbine/32263/ http://www.treehugger.com/wind-technology/silent-wind-turbines-could-generate-half-household-energy.html http://vr-zone.com/articles/efficent-wind-turbine/78905.html http://gizmodo.com/eureka-a-whisper-quiet-wind-turbine-based-on-archimede-1582606998 https://youtu.be/XUgCV2qeau8
For the turbine, you have to print it slowly.

This is a printable caterpillar robot with gear wheels and links -kind of tank-like ;) . This is part a project developed in the UC3M university in which we are designing printable robots. Here, we have together all the pieces that form this robot, but you can have a look at the different parts pages to see some other people modifications -specially at the links. Take into account that this is a work in progress.Though this robot works as it is designed now, it can be improved a lot -and this is in what we are working right now. Some of the pieces -in their own pages- are parametrized, while others are still pending. Designers: Olalla Bravo www.thingiverse.com/olalla
Daniel GÃ³mez www.thingiverse.com/dannynoc A special thank you to Obijuan www.thingiverse.com/obijuan for printing us the pieces, providing useful advice and remarking us some obvious design mistakes and, in general, leading us into the nerdy way =p . Another thank you also to our other professor Alberto, for his advice,patience and invitations to have some coffee. Individual pages for the pieces:
Gear wheels and links: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7209
Chassis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7681
Parametric gear wheels: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7794 UPDATE: We've got a video of the robot in motion!!
http://youtu.be/gRsKRrQQHos Update 4/13 23:52 The chassis now includes four drills in order to hold the PIC with the micro that controls the servos above the chassis. Also, the hole that it had so that some material could be saved has been removed in order to sustain better the PIC. Update 4/14 14:08 Added the parametric version of the gear wheels that we are using in the design. Update 4/20 00:28 The comments of the links scad file have been translated into English. I hope this will help to understand better the code and that it will make easier modifications of the file.

Chassis Parts:
-Chassis 1.3.scad: we printed a very similar one to chassis 1.3.stl
-U-front-piece: take it from Obijuan skybot chassis http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4954 The chassis is designed so that the distance of the passive wheel from the motor wheels can be slightly modified at convenience. We thought that it was a good idea in order to make sure that the caterpillar track is tensed. Wheels: Motor wheels: rueda_dentada.scad, rueda_dentada.stl
Passive wheels: rueda_dentada_arrastrada.scad, rueda_dentada_pasiva.stl They both have been extruded from rueda_dentada.dxg, the only difference between them is that ones have the wholes made in order to be fixed to the servo and the other ones just have a 3mm diameter drill so we can fix them with screws. parametric_wheels.scad is the trial of making these wheels parametrizable. The example of use (the one in parametric_wheels.stl) is supossed to be the same wheel as the ones we have mentioned before, but for the moment, those have not been printed or/and tested. Links: -eslabonoruga.scad, link.stl We are using 21 links for each track.
We are thinking about putting silicone on the links in order to increase traction -but we are waiting till we have the full two tracks to try it. Another suggestion by scocioba has been using rubbery spry.

comments.text: I knew you guys could do it! What do you think of using M3 - 25mm cap screws with nuts for the link connectors? Ill try the bot with the screws and let you know how it goes. Keep up the great work! Also may I suggest using rubberizing spray paint for the links

title: Full Graphic Smart Controller case and board 3D model

description.text:
Well, that's right… Yet ANOTHER case for the well-known LCD display and SD card reader. ;)  
I wanted to design one of my own, specially adapted for my SmartrapCore 3D printer. It's extremely simple : it's just a front case, with two holes on the side to put on the inside of the wooden box, but I'm pretty sure you can install that almost on any printer case.  
The way it's designed, it's easy to tilt it at the most convenient angle, depending on how high your printer is installed (mine is almost on the floor, so I tilted it quite much).  
In the STL file, with the case itself, you get the two buttons, and there's even an exclamation mark engraved on the emergency stop button to make it really clear what it's used for. ;)  
The Blender file includes a rather precise model of the electronic board itself, so even if you don't like my case, you have the virtual board device to design (yet another) one of your own… ;)

author: jfonollo

description.text:
I've printed lots of bottle openers from thingiverse, and they all work, but I decided I wanted a better one:
  • No metal: does not need a coin or other metal parts
  • Opens bottles easily and quickly
  • Durable, can open lots of bottles
  • Ergonomic, fits in the hand well
  • Does not bend the cap
  • Small enough to fit in pocket
  • Easy to print
    • This opener uses a curved prying edge that catches on a substantial amount of the sharp cap edge, the extra contact spreads out the opening force, so the opener is much less likely to be damaged by the cap edge. The cap lever covers the whole top of the cap to keep bending to a minimum, and the lever lip forces the cap into the opener so you only have to lift vertically to the bottle. Since the cap is barely deformed you can (in most cases) put the cap back on the bottle and save the rest of your beverage for later. This is version 9 and I think it works really well. If you think you have a better opener design, comment here and I would love to check them out.

Print and enjoy a beer.  
Print with a 1.6 to 2 mm shell, and 25% infill or higher.  
Having a thick shell is probably the most important part.of making the opener durable. I've opened around a hundred bottles so far with no problems.

comments.text: As baysail  wrote  "By far the best opener out there. Thanks for the model!"
comments.author: Kaatz

comments.text: By far the best opener out there.  Thanks for the model!
comments.author: baysail

comments.author: tronix

comments.text: I print them on using the longest edge down (like in the render of the part file) and have had good results with 0.1mm layers. If the curve/roundness of the handle is too much for your printer, try cutting off the bottom 1-2mm. This is easy to do in in Cura, but I am unsure of how to do it in other slicers.

description.text:
This thing contains a mounting plate and a drilling guide for the “Freescale FRDM-KL25Z Board”.   
The plates are not symmetrical. The notch shall be on the USB connectors' side. The base plate is 2 mm thick. M2 5 mm or 1/4″ 4-40 screws are needed to fasten the board to the mounting plate. The mounting holes are three mm in diameter.   
The holes do not go through the lower layer to make it easier to print. You will have to drill them.

Print the Z Axis Support twice for upper and lower parts and use the original screws and nuts. It must be printed with some infill to be more resistant. Beware of the warp if you print with ABS because it is a large piece.
The Ball Bearing for the upper part is 608Z.
Clean all screw holes first and place M3 nuts inside for Z rod mount.
When mounting the lower part do remove the power supply and even the Z driver from the mainboard.
On a flat surface roll the threaded rod to check if it is straight or not (the rod material is very soft unfortunately).
You can use a rigid coupler or the original flexible coupler. Many thanks for 5-8 coupler.

author: Nomonika

description.text: Tea Dispenser

i didnt have a 3d printer to print this part at first, so i substituted in an LMK8UU flange type bearing to do the job. after the printer works, i printed this to substitute the bearing for a rigid plastic part.   
hole is 8.2mm wide, allowing some tolerance for wavy z-axis prints like mine. otherwise ive included the sldprt 2014 file for your modification.  
ribs are extra thick just because. opening is chamfered to prevent the plastic from deforming inward if alignment is bad upon entry.   
best to print in pairs or slow down near the upper half after the ribs to give time to cool.

I was in need to create a planetary gears box with 5mm shaft.
All the scripts I've found here, were broken someway, so I devided to take a look at the code and fix the problems for the 5mm shaft version. I used a 625ZZ ball bearing. As you can see in other photos I posted, I've used this thing to make a reduction for my Bowden MK8 Extruder, because I recently build a Rostock and it needs a lot of torque while printing fast. It works like a charm ^^.

comments.text: how you extend the length of your shaft
comments.author: Brandonzhun

comments.text: what do you use for shaft?
comments.author: warham

comments.text: I am using your planetary gear box, great thing. I use it for my extruder motor and because of this I have radial forces on it. So I have printed the bearing twice to handle this kind of force. I think otherwise the plastic toothed are stressed to much.
comments.author: butchja

comments.text:
Try to print the gears in PET-G or Nylon (PA6 or Taulmann 610).
I personally print at a little higher temperatures to help interlayer bonding, using NOFANS on Infill and FULL FANS on perimeters. I alter the GCode using RegEx builtin in Simplify3D to turn on and off the fans where I want.
To make the polymer stronger you can "cook" it in an hoven ([email protected]°->3h / [email protected]°->4h / [email protected] NECESSARY).
comments.author: butchja

comments.text: For thouse, who will edit sCAD files and print M5 bolt version, replace "undefined_m5_bearing" & "undefined_m5_bearing_clearance" with "625_bearing" & "625_bearing_clearance" in the "raldrich_planetary.scad" file.

This is a holder I made for use in the car, which will hold a Nokia Lumia 920 and the Nokia wireless charging pad in a slot behind it. The mounting holes are configured for a vehicle-specific mount from proclipusa.com. This is a second revision based on my first try here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74303. I loosened up the phone holder area, made a slot for the camera button, rounded more edges, and removed some unnecessary mass.
This was made in 123D Design (project file attached). Just print, clean up, and mount to a custom vehicle mount or something from proclipusa.com.

A fairly basic test tube rack with holes for 5 tubes, up to 23mm diameter tubes.   
Mine is in ABS.  
In hindsight, now that it's printed (hence these machines used to be called rapid prototypers!) I would make the legs a little sturdier (therefore I have included the original .blend file for those who can use Blender.  
I didn't use a raft - see instructions!!!

Print it as is - I generally need a raft on my Rep2X - but I've figured out now to just make the first layer a little thicker by moving the whole model down by about 0.07 mm - this forces the nozzles closer to the print platform to print a bit of a thicker layer - adjust this as you see fit!!  
Once printed, "glue" the legs in the sockets with a drop of acetone (a q-tip works well), hold still while it sets (easy to flex and come apart if you try to move it before the acetone evaporates). That's it!!
We bought this Aliexpress reprap, which came with a 'Migbot' extruder. Never heard of it, but the thing isn't very stiff. Therefore I made this simple clamp, improving the print quality a lot.
Just print and place over the extruder as shown in the picture.

remixed_from.author: wulfdesign
remixed_from.title: 608 Ball Chain Idler with matching Pulley Hack

title: zRod-2-Stepper  Coupler w/3 Grub Screws for Prusa Mendels

description.text:
I found that the Z-Rod coupler for the Prusa Mendel didn't hold well so went back to the drawing board.
Wanting to be done with it and move on to printing with the Prusa ASAP I took the existing "608 Ball Chain Idler with matching Pulley Hack" and 'differenced' out the 'pulley' portion and exported the .stl
Then Changed the shaft diameter to 8mm (for the zRod) and output that to .stl, Flipped it over, and combined then in Rhino. (one stl object on top of the another effectively bonds them as one object).
I apologize that it's such a hack job but it prints (and hopefully works great) and got the job done.

Print 2 (one for each stepper)
You'll need 6 ea. of M3 nuts for the captive nuts and 6 ea. M3 x 8mm grub screws. For a total of 12each. Then I used 9,10,& 11 numbered drill bits to drill them out on the stepper end to get the tightest fit possible. I guess if you wanted you could tap the 8mm zrod end or just drill it out to 8mm (or 5/16). P.S. the numbered drill bits where something like $2ea at the local hardware vs. $6 ea. for metric. The Grub Screws where $0.19 ea.

remixed_from.title: Support bracket for Y idler on ToM

title: Support bracket for Y idler on ToM

description.text:
Derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7022 When I printed out the original, everything worked OK (re-using the axis cap and all) but I was 3mm off somehow.
Didn't feel like messing around with the STL so I made it again in openscad. The bolts are also a bit short, since they are supporting both this and the cap, but if you don't file down/drill out the holes more, they seem to actually support the bolts pretty well. If it comes off or starts to, I might change the design to have a countersink (I hope that's what it's called) for the nut to sit in - or you can just use longer bolts.
Unscrew the top 2 screws on your y-axis cap closest to the idler, put this on the idler and put the screws in. Really, follow the directions from the original.

description.text: This is just a basic plug to fill in the handle and create a fully enclosed build chamber. There are some other great design available but I created this one for its simplicity and fitment. I also have another plug design available to fill the hole when the included spools are not used: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:775823 Note: This is intended to be a tight fit but each machine has different tolerances and you may need to sand down the 6 small tabs along the edge just slightly. For instance, on the left side of my printer the design fit without any modifications, whereas, the right side required minor sanding.
Printed with ABS to withstand higher temperatures and at 0.1mm resolution to provide improved tolerances.

title: RasPi Cam Holder for Rebel II Printer

description.text:
Here is my attempt to create Raspberry Pi Camera Holder that would fit alu profiles of Rebel II (RepRap) 3d printer. Works for me, maybe it will work for you as well.  
Attached are .stl as well as Inventor files for all your tinkering needs.

I decided to print from ABS to retain some flexibility, though it is really needed only for the profile clip (Clip3). The holes are designed for M5 (Clip to stand, rail holder to camera holder) and M3 (stand to rail holder) screws. For the optimal result, use M3 tapping screw (they were used in these ancient desktop computers of old, every household must have a few of them lying around).

description.text: MTG is all about casting spells, so why not keep your spells safe in this Magical Spell Book. UPDATED: 10-9-16: NEW VERSION: Thicker hinges that are more sturdy and a new cleaner cover that doesn't require much support.

First, choose which configuration of the book you would like: STEP 1: Choose either:
Small: Holds up to 75 sleeved cards - has a spot to store one Spin Down
Large: Holds up to 150 sleeved cards STEP 2: Choose one:
Normal: Has no way to keep cover shut.
Magnet: Uses 1/8" x 1/16" Rare Earth Disc magnets to keep it shut. Super glue them in.
TieString: You can use a piece of string or ribbon to hold it shut. Once you've chosen, go to "Thing Files" and choose a zip file.
Open the zip file and you'll see that there are more choices: Back: The back cover and spine of the book. Print this with NO SUPPORTS.
Options:
symbols: has the symbol for each Mana type
nosymbols: blank Pages: The pages of the book. Print this with NO SUPPORTS.
Options:
deck: perfectly sized to put a deck with a spot for your Spin Down
empty: completely empty if you want to store your dice, counters, or anything else Cover: The front cover of the book. Print this with EXTERIOR SUPPORTS.
Options
spellbook: The words "Spell Book" are embossed.
blank: nothing is written on the cover Rod: This is the pin that goes in the hinges. Print this twice with NO SUPPORTS.
Shove the rods in the hinge holes and glue in place with super glue.

author: teammariano

title: Square drill using a Reuleaux triangle rotor

description.text:
In principle, a Reuleaux triangle -- a shape of constant width -- can be used to drill an almost square hole. I wanted a toy to illustrate the principle. So when you put this together, and turn the crank, it shows how the triangle can move to create an almost square hole. It's complicated by the fact that to drill a square hole, the center of the triangle must move, and the path it moves along is not circular. So I have joined the crank to the triangle with an Oldham coupler, which allows off-center rotation. There are a couple of other Reuleaux triangles out there:
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1082
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1088
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5456
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1755
    but they don't come with the crank :)

(1) Print one of each bit.
(2) Clean up the bits. They come out OK on my thing-o-matic. Even the overhangs are OK, however, to make them work reasonably, I made some of the bolt holes blind, so that you will need to drill these out. It should be pretty easy though. I also filled down the interior of the slots and the surfaces, just a little so there isn't anything that catches.
(3) Insert M3 nuts into each of the nut holes. They are a little tight, but better that than having them drop out all the time. Make sure internal buts as flush with the surface.
(4) Put the handle on the arm using an M3x30mm. This should be a little loose so the handle can rotate freely. Use a second nut to lock the bolt in place.
(5) Connect the handle to the larger disc. The end of the handle should just fit into the slot on the bottom of the disc (see picture). I used an M3x25mm to connect them, but you could use something longer, or a bit shorter.
(6) Put a little lubricant (your choice, but make sure it won't affect plastic) on each of the discs, and slots. You won't need much -- maybe none at all if your printer makes the parts accurately enough.
(7) Now attach the smaller disc to the larger by putting two M3x12mm nuts through the slot in the smaller disc, and into the bolt holes on the top of the larger disc. The smaller disc should be held close to the larger, but should move freely along the slot.
(8) Put the disc assembly into the bottom of the plate/box part. Put the Reuleaux triangle part on top of it all, and put two M3x12mm bolts through the slot into the bolt holes on the top of the smaller disc to fasten everything in place. Again, the bolts should be just tight enough to hold everything close together, but should allow free movement.
For best results you may want to use a little lock-tight on the nuts and bolts to stop it coming apart with time. I wouldn't do this until you are happy with the movement. It should turn freely once everything is set up right, but getting to that point is fiddly.
There's a couple of pictures showing partial assembly, and a movie showing it operating.

comments.text: Cool demo; this is definitely something that makes more sense when you can play with it.
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: The tolerances can definitely be made tighter, but the first few designs I tried, before I got the geometry of the coupler right, were very tight (they would hardly turn), so I made later models looser. With the geometry right it can be made more exact. I'm working on a new one, and that will be better.

title: Replaceable pin Iris Box with shorter compartment.

description.text: I was asked by my local Home Depot associate if I knew if of any prints that would show off the capabilities of the Dremel 3D Idea Builder better then the chess pieces and dinosaur heads they had been printing. I immediately thought of emmit's box. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8402 But when reading the comments I noticed mention that the pins were a weak point. So I modified the file to allow them to be printed separately. That way when a pin inevitably breaks, I can give them the pin file that allows them to simply replace it. This also allows for (what I would imagine would be) easier assembly as you can attach the leaves to the pins and put them in place before simply pressing the ring down on top. I included a horizontal version of the pin with support in an effort to reduce it's weakness, but those pins didn't come out very well. Additionally, I threw together a smaller version of the container in an effort to save plastic. This was made by cropping out a middle section and merging the top and bottom together. Unfortunately it has a weird inner lip where the two parts merged. Not a problem, just an oddity.

comments.text: I had the scale the pins to 0.95 as default size was to tight for them to slide in the tracks. I printed at .90 as well which was just a little loose.
